SpeciesDescription: The spot-tailed antwren (Herpsilochmus sticturus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: Salvin, 1885, no known copyright restrictions (public domain)

SpeciesDescription: The Dugand's antwren (Herpsilochmus dugandi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cody Limber, all rights reserved, uploaded by Cody Limber

SpeciesDescription: The Todd's antwren (Herpsilochmus stictocephalus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: Todd, 1927, no known copyright restrictions (public domain)

SpeciesDescription: The ancient antwren (Herpsilochmus gentryi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in northern Peru and southeastern Ecuador. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thibaud Aronson, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Thibaud Aronson

SpeciesDescription: The spot-backed antwren (Herpsilochmus dorsimaculatus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ingrid Macedo, all rights reserved, uploaded by Ingrid Macedo

SpeciesDescription: The pectoral antwren (Herpsilochmus pectoralis) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to north east Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) NINA WENÓLI, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by NINA WENÓLI

SpeciesDescription: The large-billed antwren (Herpsilochmus longirostris) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia and Brazil. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Vincent A. Vos, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Vincent A. Vos

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-winged antwren (Herpsilochmus rufimarginatus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, and Venezuela. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests, subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests, subtropical or tropical moist montane forests, and subtropical or tropical dry shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) matiasgomes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The narrow-billed antwren (Formicivora iheringi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to eastern Brazil where it occurs in Bahia and Minas Gerais states. Its natural habitat is deciduous and semi-deciduous forest between 250 and 1,050 metres above sea level. It is threatened by habitat loss. The narrow-billed antwren is sometimes put in the monotypic genus Neorhopias.
ImageAttribution: (c) Fausto Rocha Araújo, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Fausto Rocha Araújo

SpeciesDescription: The black-hooded antwren (Formicivora erythronotos) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae, the antbirds. It is endemic to Brazil, where it is known only from the vicinity of Ilha Grande Bay in the southern part of the state of Rio de Janeiro. It was collected and then not seen for 100 years until it was rediscovered in 1987. It is now known from seven sites. Its range is small and its habitat is fragmented.
ImageAttribution: (c) Bruno Siqueira, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Bruno Siqueira

SpeciesDescription: The Sincorá antwren (Formicivora grantsaui) is a small passerine bird of the genus Formicivora in the family Thamnophilidae, the typical antbirds. It is endemic to a small area of eastern Brazil. The bird was not described as a new species until 2007 (coincidentally, another species was also described from the same region in 2007, the Diamantina tapaculo). The binomial name commemorates the German-born naturalist Rolf Grantsau who collected a specimen in 1965 that was recently identified...
ImageAttribution: (c) shrike2, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by shrike2

SpeciesDescription: The ferruginous antbird (Drymophila ferruginea) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Atlantic Forest in south-eastern Brazil. It was formerly considered conspecific with the very similar Bertoni's antbird.
ImageAttribution: (c) Antonio Amaral, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Antonio Amaral

SpeciesDescription: Bertoni's antbird (Drymophila rubricollis) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in the Atlantic Forest of south-eastern Brazil, eastern Paraguay and far north-eastern Argentina (Misiones). It was formerly considered conspecific with the very similar ferruginous antbird.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cláudio Dias Timm, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-tailed antbird (Drymophila genei) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Rob Van Epps, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Rob Van Epps

SpeciesDescription: The ochre-rumped antbird (Drymophila ochropyga) is a species of bird in the antbird family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil, in the east and south east of the country in the Atlantic Forest Mountains EBA. It has fairly specific habita requirements, mostly being found in dense bamboo thickets and the thick understory of montane forest, and also more rarely in lowland evergreen forest, from 300 to 1,950 m (980–6,400 ft).
ImageAttribution: (c) Laura Gaudette, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Laura Gaudette

SpeciesDescription: The dusky-tailed antbird (Drymophila malura) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Argentina, Brazil, and Paraguay. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Maicon Molina, all rights reserved, uploaded by Maicon Molina

SpeciesDescription: The East Andean antbird (Drymophila caudata) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found at high levels in humid highland forests, especially near bamboo, and is endemic to the western slope of the Eastern Andes and the Upper Magdalena Valley in Caquetá and Huila in Colombia. This 15 cm (5.9 in) bird is found at high elevations of about 1,500-2,500 m. It was formerly considered conspecific with the Klages's antbird, the Santa Marta antbird,...
ImageAttribution: (c) Carlos Torrente, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Carlos Torrente

SpeciesDescription: The Klages's antbird (Drymophila klagesi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in humid foothill forests, from Venezuela to NE Colombia in Serranía de Perijá and the northern Eastern Andes, especially in association with bamboo. This 15 cm (6 in) bird is found at higher elevations. It was previously considered conspecific with the long-tailed antbird.
ImageAttribution: (c) Oswaldo Hernández, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Oswaldo Hernández

SpeciesDescription: The Santa Marta antbird (Drymophila hellmayri) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to humid foothill forests of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta in Colombia, especially in association with bamboo. This 15 cm (6 in) bird is found at higher elevations. It was previously considered conspecific with the long-tailed antbird.
ImageAttribution: (c) Peter Hoell, all rights reserved, uploaded by Peter Hoell

SpeciesDescription: The Guianan warbling antbird (Hypocnemis cantator) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. Until recently, it included the Imeri, Peruvian, yellow-breasted, Rondonia and Spix's warbling antbird as subspecies, but based on vocal differences and to a lesser degree differences in plumages it has been recommended treating them as separate species. As presently defined, the Guianan warbling antbird is monotypic, although the subspecies notaea sometimes has been recognized.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cláudio Dias Timm, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The Imeri warbling antbird (Hypocnemis flavescens) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. Until recently, it was considered a subspecies of Hypocnemis cantator, but based on vocal differences and to a lesser degree differences in plumages it has been recommended treating them as separate species. As presently defined, the Imeri warbling antbird includes a single subspecies, perflava.
ImageAttribution: (c) Justyn Stahl, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Justyn Stahl

SpeciesDescription: The Rondônia warbling antbird (Hypocnemis ochrogyna) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. Until recently, it was considered a subspecies of Hypocnemis cantator, but based on vocal differences and to a lesser degree differences in plumages it has been recommended treating them as separate species. As presently defined, the Rondonia warbling antbird is monotypic.
ImageAttribution: (c) Lilian Tomazelli, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Lilian Tomazelli

SpeciesDescription: The Manicoré warbling antbird (Hypocnemis rondoni) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution:
(c) 
Fabio Schunck, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The orange-bellied antwren (Terenura sicki) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Marcelo Maux, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Marcelo Maux

SpeciesDescription: The streak-capped antwren (Terenura maculata) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) A Lamberts, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by A Lamberts

SpeciesDescription: Parker's antbird (Cercomacroides parkeri) is a species of passerine bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Colombia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christoph Moning, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Christoph Moning

SpeciesDescription: The black antbird (Cercomacroides serva) is a species of passerine bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thibaud Aronson, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Thibaud Aronson

SpeciesDescription: The riparian antbird (Cercomacroides fuscicauda) is a species of passerine bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thibaud Aronson, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Thibaud Aronson

SpeciesDescription: The Manu antbird (Cercomacra manu) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, and Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cláudio Dias Timm, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The Rio de Janeiro antbird (Cercomacra brasiliana) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gabriel Bonfa, all rights reserved, uploaded by Gabriel Bonfa

SpeciesDescription: The Mato Grosso antbird (Cercomacra melanaria) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, and Paraguay. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) markus lilje, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by markus lilje

SpeciesDescription: The bananal antbird (Cercomacra ferdinandi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Marco  Cruz, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The jet antbird (Cercomacra nigricans) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) barloventomagico, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The Rio Branco antbird (Cercomacra carbonaria) is a bird species in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil (Roraima) and Guyana.
ImageAttribution: (c) Mikael Bauer, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Mikael Bauer

SpeciesDescription: The Tapajos fire-eye (Pyriglena similis) is an insectivorous bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Anderson Sandro, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Anderson Sandro

SpeciesDescription: The fringe-backed fire-eye (Pyriglena atra), also known as Swainson's fire-eye, is a rare species of bird in the antbird family that is endemic to Brazil. Names in other languages include Olho-de-fogo-rendado and papa-taoca-da-bahia in Portuguese, Batará de Swainson and Ojodefuego de Bahía in Spanish, Alapi noir and Priglène à manteau tacheté in French, and Fleckenmantel-Feuerauge and Fleckenmantel-Feueraugef in German.
ImageAttribution: (c) eduardovieira17, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by eduardovieira17

SpeciesDescription: The white-shouldered fire-eye (Pyriglena leucoptera) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is mainly found in the Atlantic Forest of southern Brazil and eastern Paraguay.
ImageAttribution: (c) Luciano Bernardes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Luciano Bernardes

SpeciesDescription: The slender antbird (Rhopornis ardesiacus) is an endangered species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is monotypic within the genus Rhopornis. It is endemic to dry forest at altitudes of 100–1,000 metres (330–3,280 ft) in Bahia and Minas Gerais in Brazil. It is threatened by habitat loss. This relatively long-tailed antbird is about 19 centimetres (7.5 in) in length. Both sexes are grey with black-and-white markings on the wings and red eyes. The male has a black...
ImageAttribution: (c) Karina Avila, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Karina Avila

SpeciesDescription: The black-tailed antbird (Myrmoborus melanurus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) David J Barton, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by David J Barton

SpeciesDescription: The white-lined antbird (Myrmoborus lophotes) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, and Peru. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Noah Frade, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Noah Frade

SpeciesDescription: The band-tailed antbird (Hypocnemoides maculicauda) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in the Amazon Basin south of the river Amazon (Bolivia, Brazil and Peru). Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical swamps and flooded forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Carmelo López Abad, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Carmelo López Abad

SpeciesDescription: The black-and-white antbird (Myrmochanes hemileucus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is monotypic within the genus Myrmochanes. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests and subtropical or tropical moist shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) shrike2, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by shrike2

SpeciesDescription: The Allpahuayo antbird (Percnostola arenarum) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to northeastern Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Beadle, all rights reserved, uploaded by David Beadle

SpeciesDescription: The slate-colored antbird (Myrmelastes schistaceus) is a species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) shrike2, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by shrike2

SpeciesDescription: The blue-winged warbler (Vermivora cyanoptera) is a fairly common New World warbler, 11.5 cm (4.5 in) long and weighing 8.5 g (0.30 oz). It breeds in eastern North America in southern Ontario and the eastern United States. Its range is extending northwards, where it is replacing the very closely related golden-winged warbler, Vermivora chrysoptera.
ImageAttribution: (c) Carl-Adam Wegenschimmel, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Carl-Adam Wegenschimmel

SpeciesDescription: The black-and-white warbler (Mniotilta varia) is a species of New World warbler, and the only member of its genus, Mniotilta.
ImageAttribution: (c) Holly Merker, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Holly Merker

SpeciesDescription: The prothonotary warbler (Protonotaria citrea) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family. It is the only member of the genus Protonotaria.
ImageAttribution: (c) Brad Moon, all rights reserved, uploaded by Brad Moon

SpeciesDescription: Swainson's warbler (Limnothlypis swainsonii) is a small species of New World warbler. It is monotypic, the only member of the genus Limnothlypis. Swainson's warbler was named after William Swainson, an English ornithologist.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The flame-throated warbler, (Oreothlypis gutturalis), is a small New World warbler. It is sometimes placed in the genera Vermivora and Parula.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thomas A. Driscoll, all rights reserved, uploaded by Thomas A. Driscoll

SpeciesDescription: The Tennessee warbler (Leiothlypis peregrina) is a New World warbler that breeds in eastern North America and winters in southern Central America and northern South America. The specific peregrina is from Latin peregrinus "wanderer".
ImageAttribution: (c) Jerry Oldenettel, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The Colima warbler (Leiothlypis crissalis) is a New World warbler. It is mainly found in the Sierra Madre Occidental and Oriental of central Mexico, though its range just barely extends into adjacent southwestern Texas in the Chisos Mountains of Big Bend National Park.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: Lucy's warbler (Leiothlypis luciae) is a small New World warbler found in North America. This species ranges includes southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is one of only two warblers to nest in cavities.
ImageAttribution: (c) BJ Stacey, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The Nashville warbler (Leiothlypis ruficapilla) is a small songbird in the New World warbler family, found in North and Central America. It breeds in parts of the northern and western United States and southern Canada, and migrates to winter in southern California and Texas, Mexico, and the north of Central America. It has a gray head and a green back, and its underparts are yellow and white.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nancy Christensen, all rights reserved, uploaded by Nancy Christensen

SpeciesDescription: Virginia's warbler (Leiothlypis virginiae) is a species of New World warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) BJ Stacey, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The Connecticut warbler (Oporornis agilis) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Pedro Genaro Rodriguez, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Pedro Genaro Rodriguez

SpeciesDescription: The masked yellowthroat (Geothlypis aequinoctialis) is a New World warbler. It has a number of separate resident breeding populations in Central and South America, some of which may be considered to form separate species.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jerome Foster, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Jerome Foster

SpeciesDescription: The southern yellowthroat (Geothlypis velata) is a New World warbler. It has a number of separate resident breeding populations in South America from southeastern Peru, eastern Bolivia, and south Amazonian Brazil to Argentina and Uruguay. It was previously considered a subspecies of the masked yellowthroat.
ImageAttribution: (c) Alexander Viduetsky, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Alexander Viduetsky

SpeciesDescription: The MacGillivray's warbler (Geothlypis tolmiei) is a species of New World warbler. These birds are sluggish and heavy warblers, preferring to spend most of their time on, or near the ground, except when singing.
ImageAttribution: (c) Rand Rudland, all rights reserved, uploaded by Rand Rudland

SpeciesDescription: The mourning warbler (Geothlypis philadelphia) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Tom Benson, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The Kentucky warbler (Geothlypis formosa) is a small species of New World warbler. It is a sluggish and heavy warbler with a short tail, preferring to spend most of its time on or near the ground, except when singing.
ImageAttribution: (c) Dan LaVorgna, all rights reserved, uploaded by Dan LaVorgna

SpeciesDescription: The Altamira yellowthroat (Geothlypis flavovelata) is a New World warbler. It is a resident breeding bird endemic to the Gulf slope of northeastern Mexico.
ImageAttribution: (c) Daniel Garza Tobón, all rights reserved, uploaded by Daniel Garza Tobón

SpeciesDescription: The whistling warbler (Catharopeza bishopi) is a species of bird in the New World warbler family. It is monotypic within the genus Catharopeza. It is endemic to the island of Saint Vincent in the Lesser Antilles. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forest and subtropical or tropical moist montane forest. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) viweedguy, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The elfin woods warbler (Setophaga angelae) is a bird endemic to Puerto Rico where it is a local and uncommon species. Discovered in 1968 and described in 1972, it is the most recently described species of New World warbler (family Parulidae). The species name, angelae, is a tribute to Angela Kepler, one of its discoverers. An insectivore, it feeds by gleaning small insects off leaves.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christoph Moning, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Christoph Moning

SpeciesDescription: The arrowhead warbler (Setophaga pharetra) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is endemic to Jamaica. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Michael Woodruff, all rights reserved, uploaded by Michael Woodruff

SpeciesDescription: The hooded warbler (Setophaga citrina) is a New World warbler. It breeds in eastern North America and across the eastern United States and into southernmost Canada (Ontario). It is migratory, wintering in Central America and the West Indies. Hooded warblers are very rare vagrants to western Europe.
ImageAttribution: (c) jtajax, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The plumbeous warbler (Setophaga plumbea) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is found only in Dominica and Guadeloupe. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) John C. Mittermeier, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: The American redstart (Setophaga ruticilla) is a New World warbler. It is unrelated to the Old World redstarts.
ImageAttribution: (c) Scott Buckel, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Scott Buckel

SpeciesDescription: Kirtland's warbler (Setophaga kirtlandii), also known as the jack pine warbler, is a small songbird of the New World warbler family (Parulidae), named after Jared P. Kirtland, an Ohio doctor and amateur naturalist. Nearly extinct just 50 years ago, it is well on its way to recovery. It requires large areas (> 160 acres) of dense young jack pine for its breeding habitat. This habitat was historically created by wildfire, but today is primarily created through...
ImageAttribution: (c) guyincognito, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by guyincognito

SpeciesDescription: The Cape May warbler (Setophaga tigrina) is a species of New World warbler. It breeds in northern North America. Its breeding range spans all but the westernmost parts of southern Canada, the Great Lakes region, and New England. It is migratory, wintering in the West Indies. This species is a very rare vagrant to western Europe, with two records in Britain as of October 2013. The English name refers to Cape May, New Jersey, where George...
ImageAttribution: (c) Quinton Moss, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Quinton Moss

SpeciesDescription: The cerulean warbler (Setophaga cerulea) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family. Adult males have pale cerulean blue and white upperparts with a black necklace across the breast and black streaks on the back and flanks. Females and immature birds have greyer or greenish upperparts, a pale stripe over the eye, and no streaking on the back and no neck. All of these birds have wing bars and a thin pointed bill. They...
ImageAttribution: (c) Matt Schenck, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Matt Schenck

SpeciesDescription: The northern parula (Setophaga americana) is a small New World warbler. It breeds in eastern North America from southern Canada to Florida.
ImageAttribution: (c) bwood708, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by bwood708

SpeciesDescription: The magnolia warbler (Setophaga magnolia) is a member of the wood warbler family Parulidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Andrew C, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: The bay-breasted warbler (Setophaga castanea) is a New World warbler. It breeds in northern North America, specifically in Canada, into the Great Lakes region, and into northern New England.
ImageAttribution: (c) Irv, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The Blackburnian warbler (Setophaga fusca ) is a small New World warbler. They breed in eastern North America, from southern Canada, westwards to the southern Canadian Prairies, the Great Lakes region and New England, to North Carolina.
ImageAttribution: (c) Matt Felperin, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Matt Felperin

SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-sided warbler (Setophaga pensylvanica) is a New World warbler. They breed in eastern North America and in southern Canada westwards to the Canadian Prairies. They also breed in the Great Lakes region and in the eastern United States.
ImageAttribution: (c) Weston Barker, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Weston Barker

SpeciesDescription: The blackpoll warbler (Setophaga striata) is a New World warbler. Breeding males are mostly black and white. They have a prominent black cap, white cheeks and white wing bars. The blackpoll breeds in forests of northern North America, from Alaska throughout most of Canada, to the mountains of New York and New England. They are a common migrant through much of North America. Come fall, they fly South to the Greater Antilles and the Northeastern coasts...
ImageAttribution: (c) Marc Faucher, all rights reserved, uploaded by Marc Faucher

SpeciesDescription: The olive-capped warbler (Setophaga pityophila) is a species of New World warbler that is native to the western and eastern ends of Cuba as well as Grand Bahama and the Abaco Islands in the Bahamas. Its natural habitat is pine forests and occasionally adjacent mixed forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jeffrey Offermann, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The pine warbler (Setophaga pinus) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The yellow-rumped warbler (Setophaga coronata) is a North American bird species combining four closely related forms: the eastern myrtle warbler (ssp coronata); its western counterpart, Audubon's warbler (ssp group auduboni); the northwest Mexican black-fronted warbler (ssp nigrifrons); and the Guatemalan Goldman's warbler (ssp goldmani).
ImageAttribution: (c) Dan Vickers, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Dan Vickers

SpeciesDescription: The Bahama warbler (Setophaga flavescens) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to The Bahamas.
ImageAttribution: (c) Tom Benson, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The prairie warbler (Setophaga discolor) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Josh Vandermeulen, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Josh Vandermeulen

SpeciesDescription: Adelaide's warbler (Setophaga adelaidae) is a bird endemic to the archipelago of Puerto Rico belonging to the Setophaga genus of the Parulidae family. The species is named after Adelaide Swift, daughter of Robert Swift, the person who captured the first specimen.
ImageAttribution: (c) Matt Felperin, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Matt Felperin

SpeciesDescription: The Barbuda warbler (Setophaga subita) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is endemic to the island of Barbuda in Antigua and Barbuda. Its natural habitat is tropical dry shrubland near wetland areas. It is threatened by habitat loss. It once was considered a subspecies of the Adelaide's warbler. In September 2017, the warbler's habitat was massively damaged by Hurricane Irma. Despite this, the species was found to have survived the storm and...
ImageAttribution: (c) Bird Explorers, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Bird Explorers

SpeciesDescription: The Saint Lucia warbler (Setophaga delicata) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to Saint Lucia. It was once considered a subspecies of the Adelaide's warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) Judd Patterson, all rights reserved, uploaded by Judd Patterson

SpeciesDescription: Townsend's warbler (Setophaga townsendi) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Bill Carpenter, all rights reserved, uploaded by Bill Carpenter

SpeciesDescription: The hermit warbler (Setophaga occidentalis) is a small perching bird. It is a species of New World warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) Frode Jacobsen, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: The golden-cheeked warbler (Setophaga chrysoparia ), also known as the gold finch of Texas, is an endangered species of bird that breeds in Central Texas, from Palo Pinto County southwestward along the eastern and southern edge of the Edwards Plateau to Kinney County. The golden-cheeked warbler is the only bird species with a breeding range confined to Texas.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The black-throated green warbler (Setophaga virens) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Zane Shantz, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Zane Shantz

SpeciesDescription: The fan-tailed warbler (Basileuterus lachrymosus) is a New World warbler in the genus Basileuterus that lives along the Pacific slope from northern Mexico to Nicaragua. Vagrant records exist for Arizona, New Mexico and Texas. It is yellow on its throat and underparts with a tawny wash on its chest. The head is gray with a black-framed yellow crown and white around the eyes. The undertail coverlets are white. They are 5.8-6.3 in (14.5–16 cm) long and have...
ImageAttribution: (c) Nigel Voaden, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: The Pirre warbler (Basileuterus ignotus) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is found in the borderline area of Panama and Colombia. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Stephen John Davies, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Stephen John Davies

SpeciesDescription: The black-eared warbler or Costa Rican warbler (Basileuterus melanotis) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It was previously considered conspecific with the three-striped warbler and the Tacarcuna warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) gwen506cr, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The three-striped warbler (Basileuterus tristriatus) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It was previously considered conspecific with the Tacarcuna warbler and the black-eared warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christian Artuso, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Christian Artuso

SpeciesDescription: The grey-headed warbler (Myiothlypis griseiceps) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is endemic to Venezuela.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jay McGowan, all rights reserved, uploaded by Jay McGowan

SpeciesDescription: The Santa Marta warbler (Myiothlypis basilica) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is endemic to the Santa Marta Mountains in Colombia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Dave Curtis, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The white-striped warbler (Myiothlypis leucophrys) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Keila Nunes Purificação, all rights reserved, uploaded by Keila Nunes Purificação

SpeciesDescription: The white-rimmed warbler or white-browed warbler (Myiothlypis leucoblephara) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is found in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests, subtropical or tropical moist montane forests, subtropical or tropical moist shrubland, and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Luciano Bernardes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Luciano Bernardes

SpeciesDescription: The black-crested warbler (Myiothlypis nigrocristata) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is found in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist montane forests and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christoph Moning, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Christoph Moning

SpeciesDescription: The Choco warbler (Myiothlypis chlorophrys) is a South American species of bird in the family Parulidae. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests, subtropical or tropical moist montane forests, and heavily degraded former forest. The bird was split from the golden-bellied warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) samzhang, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The white-lored warbler (Myiothlypis conspicillata) is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to the Santa Marta Mountains in Colombia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Arman Moreno, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Arman Moreno

SpeciesDescription: The golden-bellied warbler (Myiothlypis chrysogaster) is a South American species of bird in the Parulidae family. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests, subtropical or tropical moist montane forests, and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jorge Bedoya, all rights reserved, uploaded by Jorge Bedoya

SpeciesDescription: The Canada warbler (Cardellina canadensis) is a small boreal songbird of the New World warbler family (Parulidae). It summers in Canada and northeastern United States and winters in northern South America.
ImageAttribution: (c) Matt Felperin, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Matt Felperin

SpeciesDescription: The red-faced warbler (Cardellina rubrifrons) is a species of New World warbler.
ImageAttribution: (c) Amado Demesa, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Amado Demesa

SpeciesDescription: The pink-headed warbler (Cardellina versicolor) is a small passerine bird found in the southwestern highlands of Guatemala and the central and southeastern highlands of the Mexican state of Chiapas. The adult is primarily red, with a silvery-pink head and chest. It is a fairly common to common resident of humid to semi-humid pine-oak, pine-evergreen and evergreen forest and edge, at altitudes ranging from 1,800–3,500 m (5,900–11,500 ft) above sea level.
ImageAttribution: no rights reserved, uploaded by Adam Jackson

SpeciesDescription: The slate-throated whitestart (Myioborus miniatus), or, less accurately, the slate-throated redstart, is a species of bird in the Parulidae family.
ImageAttribution: (c) kurtongman, all rights reserved, uploaded by kurtongman

SpeciesDescription: The brown-capped whitestart or brown-capped redstart (Myioborus brunniceps) is a species of bird in the family Parulidae. It is found in humid Andean forests and woodlands in Bolivia and north-western Argentina. It sometimes includes the tepui whitestart as a subspecies.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jorge Schlemmer, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The collared whitestart or collared redstart (Myioborus torquatus) is a tropical New World warbler endemic to the mountains of Costa Rica and western Panama. Like other members of Myioborus, it is often called a "whitestart" rather than a "redstart".
ImageAttribution: (c) JeffreyGammon, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by JeffreyGammon

SpeciesDescription: The yellow-crowned whitestart (Myioborus flavivertex) or Santa Marta whitestart is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to the highland forest and woodland in the Santa Marta Mountains in Colombia. It is sometimes known by the less accurate yellow-crowned redstart.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thibaud Aronson, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Thibaud Aronson

SpeciesDescription: The white-fronted whitestart (Myioborus albifrons), or, less accurately, the white-fronted redstart, is a species of bird in the Parulidae family. It is endemic to forest and woodland in the Andes in western Venezuela. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: Kersti Nebelsiek, no known copyright restrictions (public domain)

SpeciesDescription: The tanager finch (Oreothraupis arremonops) is a songbird species. In the recent past it was placed in the Emberizidae, and then classified as its common name implies, a kind of tanager (Thraupidae). Today, it has been placed in the family Passerellidae. It is placed in the monotypic genus Oreothraupis.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christoph Moning, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Christoph Moning

SpeciesDescription: The Tacarcuna bush tanager (Chlorospingus tacarcunae) is a species of bird traditionally placed in the family Thraupidae, but now viewed closer to Arremonops in the Emberizidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jan Axel Cubilla Rodríguez, all rights reserved, uploaded by Jan Axel Cubilla Rodríguez

SpeciesDescription: The Pirre bush tanager (Chlorospingus inornatus) is a species of bird traditionally placed in the family Thraupidae, but now viewed closer to Arremonops in the Emberizidae. It is endemic to Panama. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Carmelo López Abad, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Carmelo López Abad

SpeciesDescription: The Tumbes sparrow (Rhynchospiza stolzmanni) is a species of bird in the family Emberizidae found in Ecuador and Peru. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical dry shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Beadle, all rights reserved, uploaded by David Beadle

SpeciesDescription: The Yungas sparrow (Rhynchospiza dabbenei) is a species of bird in the family Passerellidae endemic to the Southern Andean Yungas of southeastern Bolivia and northwestern Argentina. It was formerly considered a subspecies of what was then called the stripe-capped sparrow (R. strigiceps).
ImageAttribution: (c) Sebastián Lescano, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Sebastián Lescano

SpeciesDescription: The stripe-capped sparrow (Rhynchospiza strigiceps) is a species of bird in the family Passerellidae. It is found in Argentina, western Paraguay and southeastern Bolivia. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical dry shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jorge Schlemmer, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-winged sparrow (Peucaea carpalis) is a medium-small, long-tailed American sparrow with a gray face and rusty crown and supercilium; the rufous lesser coverts of the wing for which it is named are often concealed.
ImageAttribution: (c) David C Vincent, all rights reserved, uploaded by David C Vincent

SpeciesDescription: The cinnamon-tailed sparrow (Peucaea sumichrasti) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family that is endemic to Mexico.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ryan Shaw, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The black-chested sparrow (Peucaea humeralis) is a species of bird in the Passerellidae family that is endemic to Mexico.
ImageAttribution: (c) Arturo Riquer, all rights reserved, uploaded by Arturo Riquer

SpeciesDescription: The bridled sparrow (Peucaea mystacalis) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family that is endemic to Mexico. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical high-altitude shrubland. The species are brown coloured.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nigel Voaden, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: Cassin's sparrow (Peucaea cassinii) is a medium-sized sparrow.
ImageAttribution: (c) Roberto González, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Roberto González

SpeciesDescription: The grassland sparrow (Ammodramus humeralis) is a species of bird in the family Passerellidae. It is found in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana, Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay, and Venezuela. Its natural habitats are dry savannah, subtropical or tropical seasonally wet or flooded lowland grassland, and pastureland.
ImageAttribution: (c) Diego Caballero, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Diego Caballero

SpeciesDescription: The Tocuyo sparrow (Arremonops tocuyensis) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family that is found in Colombia and cities like Tocuyo and Lara of Venezuela. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical dry shrubland. The species' name comes from Tocuyo de la Costa, a town in Venezuela, which it inhabits.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christoph Moning, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Christoph Moning

SpeciesDescription: The clay-colored sparrow or clay-coloured sparrow (Spizella pallida) is a small sparrow of North America.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The field sparrow (Spizella pusilla) is a small New World sparrow in the family Emberizidae. It is about 140 mm (6 in) long and weighs about 12.5 g (0.4 oz). The head is grey with a rust-coloured crown, white eye-ring and pink bill. The upper parts are brown streaked with black and buff, the breast is buff, the belly is white and the tail is forked. There are two different colour morphs, one being greyer and the other more rufous.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: Worthen's sparrow (Spizella wortheni) is a species of American sparrow that is endemic to northeastern Mexico. It was first described by Robert Ridgway in 1884 and named for the American naturalist Charles K. Worthen. This small bird has been listed as endangered by the IUCN since 1994.
ImageAttribution: (c) Juan Cruzado Cortés, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Juan Cruzado Cortés

SpeciesDescription: The lark bunting (Calamospiza melanocorys) is a medium-sized American sparrow native to central and western North America. It is also the state bird of Colorado.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The Costa Rican brush finch or grey-striped brush finch (Arremon costaricensis) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family. It is found in the undergrowth of humid forests, especially near the edges, at altitudes of 300 to 1,200 metres (980 to 3,940 ft) in Panama and Costa Rica.
ImageAttribution: (c) Daniel Garrigues, all rights reserved, uploaded by Daniel Garrigues

SpeciesDescription: The Sierra Nevada brush finch (Arremon basilicus) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ken Chamberlain, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ken Chamberlain

SpeciesDescription: The Perijá brush finch (Arremon perijanus) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Oscar Marín, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Oscar Marín

SpeciesDescription: The Caracas brush finch (Arremon phaeopleurus) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Manuel A. Pérez R., some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Manuel A. Pérez R.

SpeciesDescription: The Paria brush finch (Arremon phygas) is a species of bird in the Passerellidae family. It is found in the undergrowth of humid forests, especially near the edges, at altitudes of 300 to 1,200 metres (980 to 3,940 ft) in the Venezuelan Coastal Range.
ImageAttribution: (c) Oswaldo Hernández, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Oswaldo Hernández

SpeciesDescription: The black-capped sparrow (Arremon abeillei) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family.
ImageAttribution: (c) Josh Vandermeulen, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Josh Vandermeulen

SpeciesDescription: The Marañón sparrow (Arremon nigriceps) is a passerine of bird in the New World sparrow family Passerellidae that is found in the Marañón River basin of northern Peru. The species was formerly considered to be conspecific with the black-capped sparrow (Arremon abeillei).
ImageAttribution: (c) David F. Belmonte, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by David F. Belmonte

SpeciesDescription: The golden-winged sparrow (Arremon schlegeli) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family that can found in Colombia and Venezuela. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests and subtropical or tropical dry shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ad Konings, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ad Konings

SpeciesDescription: The pectoral sparrow (Arremon taciturnus) is a species of bird in the family Emberizidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Suriname, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests. The Brazilian name for this species is tico-tico-de-bico-preto, which in translation means "black billed sparrow".
ImageAttribution: (c) eduardovieira17, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by eduardovieira17

SpeciesDescription: The São Francisco sparrow (Arremon franciscanus) is a species of bird in the Passerellidae family that is endemic to Brazil. The species were described in 1997 by Marcos Raposo in his book Ararajuba. The species feeds on caatinga and can be found in the valley of Rio São Francisco and in the states such as Bahia and Minas Gerais. Unlike its cousins the pectoral and half-collared sparrows, the São Francisco sparrow has a full breast band,...
ImageAttribution: (c) Caroline Reis, all rights reserved, uploaded by Caroline Reis

SpeciesDescription: The half-collared sparrow (Arremon semitorquatus) is a species of bird in the family Emberizidae. It is endemic to southeastern Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Maicon Molina, all rights reserved, uploaded by Maicon Molina

SpeciesDescription: The moss-backed sparrow (Arremon dorbignii), also known as the stripe-crowned sparrow, is a species of bird in the family Passerellidae, the New World sparrows. It is found in South America from central Bolivia to northwestern Argentina.
ImageAttribution: (c) Adrian Braidotti, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Adrian Braidotti

SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-capped brush finch (Arremon brunneinucha), is a passerine bird which breeds in highlands from central Mexico to south-eastern Peru. Despite its name, it is not a true finch, but rather a member of the large Emberizidae family, which also includes buntings, American sparrows, juncos and towhees. Until recently, it was generally placed in the genus Buarremon, while it occasionally has been placed in Atlapetes.
ImageAttribution: (c) Enrique Giron, all rights reserved, uploaded by Enrique Giron

SpeciesDescription: The sooty-faced finch (Arremon crassirostris) is a species of bird in the Emberizidae family. Until recently, it was placed in the genus Lysurus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steven Easley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Steven Easley

SpeciesDescription: The olive finch (Arremon castaneiceps) is a species of bird in the Passerellidae family. Until recently, it was placed in the genus Lysurus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ryne Rutherford, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ryne Rutherford

SpeciesDescription: The dark-eyed junco (Junco hyemalis) is a species of the juncos, a genus of small grayish American sparrows. This bird is common across much of temperate North America and in summer ranges far into the Arctic. It is a very variable species, much like the related fox sparrow (Passerella iliaca), and its systematics are still not completely untangled.
ImageAttribution: (c) Craig K. Hunt, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Craig K. Hunt

SpeciesDescription: The Guadalupe junco (Junco insularis) is a bird endemic to Guadalupe Island off Pacific Mexico. Many taxonomic authorities classified it in 2008 as asubspecies of the dark-eyed junco. In 2016, it was classified as full species.
ImageAttribution: (c) John McCormack, all rights reserved, uploaded by John McCormack

SpeciesDescription: Baird's junco (Junco bairdi) is a species of junco, small American sparrows. It is endemic to the southern Baja California Peninsula in Mexico. It previously was considered a subspecies of the yellow-eyed junco.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steven Mlodinow, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Steven Mlodinow

SpeciesDescription: The volcano junco (Junco vulcani) is an American sparrow endemic to the high mountains of Costa Rica and western Panama.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nick Moore, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Nick Moore

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-collared sparrow or Andean sparrow (Zonotrichia capensis) is an American sparrow found in a wide range of habitats, often near humans, from the extreme south-east of Mexico to Tierra del Fuego, and on the island of Hispaniola. It is famous for its diverse vocalizations, which have been intensely studied since the 1970s, particularly by Paul Handford and Stephen C. Lougheed (UWO), Fernando Nottebohm (Rockefeller University) and Pablo Luis Tubaro (UBA). Local names for this bird...
ImageAttribution: (c) Esteban Poveda, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Esteban Poveda

SpeciesDescription: The white-crowned sparrow (Zonotrichia leucophrys) is a medium-sized sparrow native to North America.
ImageAttribution: (c) uzun, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by uzun

SpeciesDescription: The golden-crowned sparrow (Zonotrichia atricapilla) is a large American sparrow found in the western part of North America.
ImageAttribution: (c) steve_ha, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The Harris's sparrow (Zonotrichia querula) is a large sparrow. Their breeding habitat is the north part of central Canada (primarily the Northwest Territories and Nunavut, ranging slightly into northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan). In fact, this bird is Canada's only endemic breeder. In the winter they migrate to the Great Plains states of the United States, from lower South Dakota to upper Texas. The common name of this species commemorates the American amateur ornithologist Edward Harris (1799–1863).
ImageAttribution: (c) Norm Townsend, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The white-throated sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis) is a passerine bird of the American sparrow family Passerellidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Judy Gallagher, some rights reserved (CC BY)

SpeciesDescription: The sagebrush sparrow (Artemisiospiza nevadensis) is a medium-sized sparrow of the western United States and northwestern Mexico. It used to be placed in the genus Amphispiza, but evidence from 2007 and 2009 suggested it be placed in its own genus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Mason Maron, all rights reserved, uploaded by Mason Maron

SpeciesDescription: The LeConte’s sparrow (Ammospiza leconteii) is one of the smallest sparrow species in North America.
ImageAttribution: (c) Greg Lasley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Greg Lasley

SpeciesDescription: The Savannah sparrow (Passerculus sandwichensis) is a small American sparrow. It is the only widely accepted member of the genus Passerculus. Comparison of mtDNA NADH dehydrogenase subunit 2 and 3 sequences indicates that the Ipswich sparrow, formerly usually considered a valid species (as Passerculus princeps), is a well-marked subspecies of the Savannah sparrow, whereas the southwestern large-billed sparrow should be recognized as a distinct species (Passerculus rostratus).
ImageAttribution: (c) Juan Miguel Artigas Azas, all rights reserved, uploaded by Juan Miguel Artigas Azas

SpeciesDescription: Baird's sparrow (Ammodramus bairdii) is a species of North American birds in the family Passerellidae of order Passeriformes. It is a migratory bird native to the United States, Canada, and Mexico.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gerardo Marrón, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Gerardo Marrón

SpeciesDescription: The Sierra Madre sparrow (Xenospiza baileyi), also known as Bailey's sparrow, is an endangered, range-restricted, enigmatic American sparrow. It is endemic to Mexico and is threatened with extinction through habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Felipe Eduardo San Martín González, all rights reserved, uploaded by Felipe Eduardo San Martín González

SpeciesDescription: The song sparrow (Melospiza melodia) is a medium-sized American sparrow. Among the native sparrows in North America, it is easily one of the most abundant, variable and adaptable species.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ad Konings, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ad Konings

SpeciesDescription: The swamp sparrow (Melospiza georgiana) is a medium-sized sparrow related to the song sparrow.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ad Konings, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ad Konings

SpeciesDescription: The large-footed finch, (Pezopetes capitalis), is a passerine bird which is endemic to the highlands of Costa Rica and western Panama. Despite its name, it is not a true finch, but rather a member of the large Emberizidae family, which also includes buntings, American sparrows, juncos and towhees. It is the only member of the genus Pezopetes.
ImageAttribution: (c) Carmelo López Abad, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Carmelo López Abad

SpeciesDescription: The Abert's towhee (Melozone aberti) is a bird of the family Emberizidae, native to a small range in southwestern North America, generally the lower Colorado River and Gila River watersheds, nearly endemic to Arizona, but also present in small parts of California, Nevada, Utah, New Mexico, and Sonora in Mexico. The name of this bird commemorates the American ornithologist James William Abert (1820–1897).
ImageAttribution: (c) BJ Stacey, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The California towhee (Melozone crissalis) is a bird of the family Passerellidae, native to the coastal regions of western Oregon and California in the United States and Baja California Sur in Mexico.
ImageAttribution: (c) Lucina M, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: Prevost's ground sparrow (Melozone biarcuata), also known as the white-faced ground sparrow, is an American sparrow.
ImageAttribution: (c) Chris Rohrer, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Chris Rohrer

SpeciesDescription: Cabanis's ground sparrow (Melozone cabanisi), is an American sparrow. It previously was considered a subspecies of the Prevost's ground sparrow.
ImageAttribution: (c) Bernardo López Miranda, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Bernardo López Miranda

SpeciesDescription: The Oaxaca sparrow (Aimophila notosticta) is a species of bird in the family Emberizidae that is endemic to the Mexican state of Oaxaca, where it lives in dry forests and thornscrub. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Manuel Grosselet, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Manuel Grosselet

SpeciesDescription: The plumbeous antbird (Myrmelastes hyperythrus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Marcel Holyoak, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The Humaita antbird (Myrmelastes humaythae) is a species of passerine bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in humid forest in the south-western Amazon in Brazil and Bolivia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Hector Bottai, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-faced antbird (Myrmelastes rufifacies) is a species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) fabiomanfredini, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by fabiomanfredini

SpeciesDescription: The dull-mantled antbird (Sipia laemosticta) is a perching bird species in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Colombia, Costa Rica, and Panama.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steven Easley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Steven Easley

SpeciesDescription: The Magdalena antbird (Sipia palliata) is a Near Threatened species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Colombia and Venezuela.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nick Athanas, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The stub-tailed antbird (Myrmeciza berlepschi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Colombia and Ecuador. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Annie Meyer, all rights reserved, uploaded by Annie Meyer

SpeciesDescription: The stub-tailed antbird (Myrmeciza berlepschi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Colombia and Ecuador. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Sebastián Pardo, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Sebastián Pardo

SpeciesDescription: The Cordillera Azul antbird (Myrmoderus eowilsoni) is a species of passerine bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It has been found only in the Cordillera Azul, San Martín Region, Peru where its natural habitat is humid montane forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Oscar Johnson, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Oscar Johnson

SpeciesDescription: The white-bibbed antbird (Myrmoderus loricatus) is a species of passerine bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Hector Bottai, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The squamate antbird (Myrmoderus squamosus) is a species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Luciano Bernardes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Luciano Bernardes

SpeciesDescription: The white-shouldered antbird (Akletos melanoceps) is a species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Justyn Stahl, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Justyn Stahl

SpeciesDescription: Goeldi's antbird (Akletos goeldii) is a species of bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Bolivia, Brazil and Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cláudio Dias Timm, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The Yapacana antbird (Aprositornis disjuncta) is a species of passerine bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela.
ImageAttribution: (c) Manakin Nature Tours, all rights reserved, uploaded by Manakin Nature Tours

SpeciesDescription: The grey-bellied antbird (Ammonastes pelzelni) is a species of passerine bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela.
ImageAttribution: (c) Mike Melton, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Mike Melton

SpeciesDescription: The white-throated antbird (Oneillornis salvini) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil and Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ben Hayden, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by Ben Hayden

SpeciesDescription: The lunulated antbird (Oneillornis lunulatus) is a species of insectivorous bird in subfamily Thamnophilinae of family Thamnophilidae, the "typical antbirds". It is found in Ecuador and Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) desertnaturalist, some rights reserved (CC BY), uploaded by desertnaturalist

SpeciesDescription: The bare-eyed antbird (Rhegmatorhina gymnops), occasionally known as the Santarem antbird, is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) rdwilcox51, all rights reserved, uploaded by rdwilcox51

SpeciesDescription: The harlequin antbird (Rhegmatorhina berlepschi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gustavo Gonsioroski, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Gustavo Gonsioroski

SpeciesDescription: The white-breasted antbird (Rhegmatorhina hoffmannsi) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gustavo Gonsioroski, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Gustavo Gonsioroski

SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-crested antbird (Rhegmatorhina cristata) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Brazil and Colombia. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Manakin Nature Tours, all rights reserved, uploaded by Manakin Nature Tours

SpeciesDescription: The dot-backed antbird (Hylophylax punctulatus) is a species of bird in the family Thamnophilidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Peru, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical swamps.
ImageAttribution: (c) Cláudio Dias Timm, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The brown tanager (Orchesticus abeillei) is a small passerine bird and a member of the tanager family. It is the only member of the genus Orchesticus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ria Vogels, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ria Vogels

SpeciesDescription: The white-bellied seedsnipe (Attagis malouinus) is a species of bird in the Thinocoridae family. It is found in southwestern Argentina and Tierra del Fuego. It is a vagrant to the Falkland Islands. Its natural habitats are temperate grassland and swamps.
ImageAttribution: (c) Paul G. Schrijvershof, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Paul G. Schrijvershof

SpeciesDescription: The red-crested cardinal (Paroaria coronata) is a songbird, the species belonging to the family of the tanagers (Thraupidae). Notwithstanding its similar name, this bird is not closely related to the true cardinal family (Cardinalidae).
ImageAttribution: (c) GUSTAVO PASCUAS, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by GUSTAVO PASCUAS

SpeciesDescription: The red-cowled cardinal (Paroaria dominicana) is a bird species in the tanager family (Thraupidae). It was formerly placed in the Emberizidae and is not very closely related to the cardinals proper (Cardinalidae).
ImageAttribution: (c) Norton Santos, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Norton Santos

SpeciesDescription: The masked cardinal (Paroaria nigrogenis) is a bird species in the tanager family (Thraupidae). It was formerly placed in the Emberizidae and is not very closely related to the cardinals proper (Cardinalidae).
ImageAttribution: (c) barloventomagico, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The cinnamon tanager (Schistochlamys ruficapillus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Argentina, Brazil, and Paraguay. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests, dry savanna, subtropical or tropical dry shrubland, and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gaell Mainguy, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Gaell Mainguy

SpeciesDescription: The shrike-like tanager (Neothraupis fasciata), also known as the white-banded tanager, is the only member of the genus Neothraupis in the tanager family (Thraupidae), nine-primaried oscines of the Passeroidea.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nick Athanas, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The black-and-white tanager (Conothraupis speculigera) is a tanager found in the Tumbes region of southwestern Ecuador and northwestern Peru; it migrates eastwards as far as Acre. The only other member of its genus is the recently rediscovered cone-billed tanager.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jhon Romero, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Jhon Romero

SpeciesDescription: The cone-billed tanager (Conothraupis mesoleuca) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Brazil.
ImageAttribution: (c) Wagner Alvim, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Wagner Alvim

SpeciesDescription: The scarlet-throated tanager (Compsothraupis loricata) is a small passerine bird. It is placed in the tanager family, although highly aberrant, with some even having suggested that it could be a corvid or icterid. It is the only member of the genus Compsothraupis.
ImageAttribution: (c) Richard Yank, all rights reserved, uploaded by Richard Yank

SpeciesDescription: The white-capped tanager (Sericossypha albocristata) is the heaviest but not the longest species of tanager, at a weight of 114 g (4 oz) and a length of 24 cm (9.5 in). This species is glossy black overall with a large white crown and a red throat (which is brightest in adult males). It occurs in Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Peru at elevations of 1600–3200 m. It lives in humid forest in groups of up to 20 individuals. Flocks of these tanagers...
ImageAttribution: (c) David Cook, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The cherry-throated tanager (Nemosia rourei) is a medium-sized passerine bird. This critically endangered tanager is an endemic to handful of localities in the Atlantic Forest in Espírito Santo, Brazil, though the possibility that it occurs in adjacent parts of Minas Gerais and Rio de Janeiro cannot be discounted. It has a striking, essentially black-white-red plumage; a photo is online in the abstract of Bauer et al. 1998.
ImageAttribution: (c) Gabriel Bonfa, all rights reserved, uploaded by Gabriel Bonfa

SpeciesDescription: The rufous-crested tanager (Creurgops verticalis) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jeff Harding, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Jeff Harding

SpeciesDescription: The slaty tanager (Creurgops dentatus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Bolivia and Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Beadle, all rights reserved, uploaded by David Beadle

SpeciesDescription: The black-capped hemispingus (Kleinothraupis atropileus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in the Andes mountains of Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Josh Vandermeulen, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by Josh Vandermeulen

SpeciesDescription: The orange-browed hemispingus (Kleinothraupis calophrys) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae found in Bolivia and far eastern Peru. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Rodrigo Wilber Soria Auza, all rights reserved, uploaded by Rodrigo Wilber Soria Auza

SpeciesDescription: Parodi's hemispingus (Kleinothraupis parodii) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae, endemic to Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Dominic Sherony, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The grey-capped hemispingus (Kleinothraupis reyi) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae that is endemic to Venezuela.
ImageAttribution: (c) Fernando Flores, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The buff-bellied tanager (Thlypopsis inornata) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) lauriekoepke, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-headed tanager (Thlypopsis pyrrhocoma) is a species of bird in the tanager family Thraupidae this is found in the Atlantic Forest of southeast Brazil, eastern Paraguay and far northeastern Argentina. It was formerly the only member of the genus Pyrrhocoma but is now placed in Thlypopsis.
ImageAttribution: (c) Frederico Acaz Sonntag, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Frederico Acaz Sonntag

SpeciesDescription: The rust-and-yellow tanager (Thlypopsis ruficeps) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Argentina, Bolivia, and Peru. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist montane forests and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) David F. Belmonte, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by David F. Belmonte

SpeciesDescription: The brown-flanked tanager (Thlypopsis pectoralis) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christian Nunes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Christian Nunes

SpeciesDescription: The plain-tailed warbling finch (Microspingus alticola) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Peru.
ImageAttribution: (c) Thibaud Aronson, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by Thibaud Aronson

SpeciesDescription: The buff-throated warbling finch (Microspingus lateralis) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in forest borders and woodland in south-eastern Brazil. It was previously considered conspecific with the gray-throated warbling finch, and together they were known as the red-rumped warbling finch. The SACC found enough evidence to split them in 2009.
ImageAttribution: (c) Eden Fontes, all rights reserved, uploaded by Eden Fontes

SpeciesDescription: The gray-throated warbling finch (Microspingus cabanisi) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in forest borders and woodland in south-eastern Brazil, far eastern Paraguay, far north-eastern Argentina, and Uruguay. It was previously considered conspecific with the buff-throated warbling finch, and together they were known as the red-rumped warbling finch. The SACC found enough evidence to split them in 2009.
ImageAttribution: (c) Arthur Alves, all rights reserved, uploaded by Arthur Alves

SpeciesDescription: The black-capped warbling finch (Microspingus melanoleucus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and western Uruguay. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forests, subtropical or tropical dry shrubland, and subtropical or tropical high-altitude shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jorge Schlemmer, all rights reserved

SpeciesDescription: The cinereous warbling finch (Microspingus cinereus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Brazil. The term cinereous describes its colouration. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical dry lowland grassland. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Hudson Martins Soares, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Hudson Martins Soares

SpeciesDescription: The three-striped hemispingus (Microspingus trifasciatus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) David F. Belmonte, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by David F. Belmonte

SpeciesDescription: The pardusco (Nephelornis oneilli) is a species of tanager that is endemic to woodland near the timberline in the Andes of central Peru. It is monotypic within the genus Nephelornis. This small olive-brown bird is typically seen in groups, which sometimes join mixed species flocks. It has a small range, but is locally fairly common, and consequently considered to be of least concern by BirdLife International and IUCN.
ImageAttribution: (c) Christian Nunes, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Christian Nunes

SpeciesDescription: The Inti tanager (Heliothraupis oneilli), also known as the San Pedro tanager, is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is the only member of the genus Heliothraupis. It is restricted to the lower Yungas of western Bolivia and southern Peru. Despite its striking coloration, call, and evolutionary distinctiveness, it was only described in 2021, and the bird's discovery and documentation to Western science only occurred during the prior two decades.
ImageAttribution: (c) abcdefgewing, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by abcdefgewing

SpeciesDescription: The yellow-crested tanager (Loriotus rufiventer) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in the western Amazon Basin (Peru, Acre and northwestern Bolivia). Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) OlegRozhko, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by OlegRozhko

SpeciesDescription: The tawny-crested tanager (Tachyphonus delatrii) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests, subtropical or tropical moist montane forests, and heavily degraded former forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Guillermo Nagy Aramacao Tours, all rights reserved, uploaded by Guillermo Nagy Aramacao Tours

SpeciesDescription: The ruby-crowned tanager (Tachyphonus coronatus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in the southern areas of Brazil and the Atlantic Forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ricardo Mitidieri, all rights reserved, uploaded by Ricardo Mitidieri

SpeciesDescription: The white-lined tanager (Tachyphonus rufus) is a medium-sized passerine bird in the tanager family Thraupidae. It is a resident breeder from Costa Rica south to northern Argentina, and on the islands of Trinidad and Tobago.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Cook Wildlife Photography, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

SpeciesDescription: The red-shouldered tanager (Tachyphonus phoenicius) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) barloventomagico, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)

SpeciesDescription: The black-throated shrike-tanager (Lanio aurantius) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Arnoldo Villaseñor, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA), uploaded by Arnoldo Villaseñor

SpeciesDescription: The masked crimson tanager (Ramphocelus nigrogularis) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical swamps and subtropical or tropical moist shrubland.
ImageAttribution: (c) Rudy Gelis, all rights reserved, uploaded by Rudy Gelis

SpeciesDescription: The vermilion tanager (Calochaetes coccineus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is the only member of its genus Calochaetes.
ImageAttribution: (c) OlegRozhko, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by OlegRozhko

SpeciesDescription: The blue-backed tanager (Cyanicterus cyanicterus) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is the only member of the genus Cyanicterus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ingrid Macedo, all rights reserved, uploaded by Ingrid Macedo

SpeciesDescription: The black-and-gold tanager (Bangsia melanochlamys) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Colombia.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Monroy R, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by David Monroy R

SpeciesDescription: The golden-chested tanager (Bangsia rothschildi) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Colombia and Ecuador. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests and subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Michael Retter, all rights reserved, uploaded by Michael Retter

SpeciesDescription: The moss-backed tanager (Bangsia edwardsi) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is found in Colombia and Ecuador. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests and subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Eric Carpenter, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Eric Carpenter

SpeciesDescription: The gold-ringed tanager (Bangsia aureocincta) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It is endemic to Colombia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Francesco Veronesi, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The yellow-green tanager (Bangsia flavovirens) is a species of bird in the family Thraupidae. It was formerly known as the yellow-green bush tanager or yellow-green chlorospingus as it used to be placed in the genus Chlorospingus with other bush tanagers. Chlorospingus as a whole was formerly placed in the tanager family Thraupidae, but was transferred to the New World sparrows when genetic analysis of two Chlorospingus species revealed they were embedded within the latter family. However,
ImageAttribution: (c) Nick Athanas, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The orange-throated tanager (Wetmorethraupis sterrhopteron) is a threatened species of bird found very locally in humid forests around the Ecuador-Peru border. It is the only member of the genus Wetmorethraupis, named after the ornithologist Alexander Wetmore. It is closely related to another genus of tanagers, Bangsia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Eric Carpenter, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Eric Carpenter

SpeciesDescription: The masked mountain tanager (Tephrophilus wetmorei) is a vulnerable species of bird in the tanager family Thraupidae. It is the only member of the genus Tephrophilus. This large and colourful tanager is endemic to elfin forest, woodland and shrub in the Andean highlands of southern Colombia, Ecuador and northern Peru. It is generally rare or uncommon, and is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Francesco Veronesi, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

SpeciesDescription: The golden-backed mountain tanager (Cnemathraupis aureodorsalis) is an endangered species of bird in the tanager family. This large and brightly colored tanager is endemic to elfin forests in the Andean highlands of central Peru. It is threatened by habitat loss.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nick Athanas, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)
